@seankearney it looks like the appveyor build failed https://ci.appveyor.com/project/sayedihashimi/package-web/build/1.0.6

I made things a little more simple. This PR is showing basic usage of GitVersion and how it can auto-version the nupkg for us. 

You will notice that this build created a nupkg with version `1.1.9-pullrequest0078` while your manual versioning is already at `1.1.16.3`. GitVersion has some conventions that help it determine what version is calculated. Part of that calculation requires tagging of the repo. The last tag in the repo was `1.1.8.1`. If the repo is tagged with `1.1.16` then the next build would be correctly numbered.

@seankearney that is pretty cool and seems useful as well. I won't have much time to work on it though, I'm really bogged down on a few other projects. You've already helped out a lot on the project so I can make you a contributor and if you'd like to run with it I'm all for that. I'll send over an invite.

What are your thoughts on publishing every build to nuget.org? Were you looking to keep prerelease nupkgs on AppVeyor and only final relesases on NuGet?

@seankearney wouldn't every build be overkill? Appveyor already has a project feed which we can publish each build to if we like. From there we can configure VS to use that for CI packages. 

I'm not strongly against it, if you think its a good idea and if we can label the package as `-build` I think its ok.
@sayedihashimi - move this convo back to Issue #77 ?

:+1:  Nice move! 

Now that there is an automated build, may I suggest using SemVer + [GitVersion](https://github.com/ParticularLabs/GitVersion) to auto version the NuGet package and the [version in the script](https://github.com/sayedihashimi/package-web/blob/master/src/Publish-Interactive.ps1#L15)?
@seankearney can you be more specific?

First, why not move towards using a simple SemVer versioning scheme? If moving to that isn't a problem then using a tool like GitVersion can help automate the versioning of the NuGet package.

The version number is hard coded in the [Publish-Interactive](https://github.com/sayedihashimi/package-web/blob/master/src/Publish-Interactive.ps1#L15) file (currently reading 1.1.11.beta4). I'm not sure that is actually used so either remove that or automaticaly update that at build time.

Currently you have to update the [.nuspec](https://github.com/sayedihashimi/package-web/blob/master/src/Nuget/Package.nuspec) with the version number. The build script can leverage GitVersion to determine the version of the build. (i.e. 1.2.3 or 1.2.3.beta5) and automatically set the .nuspec.
Take a look at [Pull Request 78](https://github.com/sayedihashimi/package-web/pull/78)

Regarding the last checkbox:
AppVeyor is currently building all branches, correct? When it builds a non-master branch lets push the artifacts to the AppVeyor feed. When it builds the master branch lets push to the NuGet.org feed.

> AppVeyor is currently building all branches, correct?

Correct

> When it builds a non-master branch lets push the artifacts to the AppVeyor feed. When it builds the master branch lets push to the NuGet.org feed.

How about this, when we push to `release` branch (_yet to be created_) we release to nuget.org for all other branches we publish to AppVeyor feed? That way we can keep the latest and greatest in `master` and just merge to `release` when we want to go to nuget.org. If you feel strongly about your direction I'm ok with that as well. I just prefer to keep the latest code in the default branch in github.

@rmagruder thanks for the report. Can you include some steps so that I can reproduce the issue? With the current info I don't have enough to try out exactly what you are seeing.

Building a web service that has an APP_DATA folder which has stuff that has to be deployed.  I build and deploy, and run the interactive deploy.

   IIS Web Application Name: Default Web Site/MySiteName
        new value>
    Add write permission to App_Data Folder: {IIS Web Application Name}/App_Data
        new value>

Now, if I Just hit <enter> here to accept it: 

Info: Updating file (Default Web Site/MySiteName\Web.config).
Info: Object dirPath (website_Deploy_) skipped due to skip directive 'CommandLineSkipDirective 1'.
Info: Object dirPath (website_Package) skipped due to skip directive 'CommandLineSkipDirective 3'.
Info: Adding ACL's for path (Default Web Site/MySiteName)
Info: Adding ACL's for path (Default Web Site/MySiteName)
Info: Adding ACL's for path ({IIS Web Application Name}/App_Data)
Error Code: ERROR_SITE_DOES_NOT_EXIST
More Information: Site '{IIS Web Application Name}' does not exist.  Learn more at: http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?Link
Id=221672#ERROR_SITE_DOES_NOT_EXIST.
Error count: 1.

As you can see, when it came to App_Data, the site didn't get substituted?  

The Parameters.xml in the project folder contains the appropriate Key/Value pair, so I just don't understand why it messes up trying to add ACL's for the App_Data subfolder?

Hi, sorry for the long layover, been working on other things.  I did some single step debugging of publish-interactive.ps1.  Looks like the bracketed variable name is emitted into the parameters file by on the build-side of package-web, not the part where the publish happened.  By the time publish-interactive.ps1 sees the {IIS Web Application Name}/App_Data, it is  getting this from the parameters file that was built.  So, I'm guessing the problem is a fail to do the subsitution at build time.

Side note:
In general, I think the biggest issue I'm having is how finicky the parameters are at publish time, So much so, that I am trying to think of a way to simplify things for the people doing the deployments.  The only two parameters I think my deployers should care about are the name of the config transform and the target server (without any Default Web Site/msdeploy.axd?....) stuff.  So just "Sqa" and "MySqaServer" with everything else 'just working', but because of how finicky the server name is, and the fact that all the other parameters, such as authentication, app_Data path name, etc  and even connection string (!) need to be specified, it seems that file based config is preferred, even though it's more error prone (what if you left the wrong config.ps1 file laying there from a previous deploy and then run the script -- deployed to the wrong place!)

This item is a duplicate of the previous issue #60. Let's continue the conversation over there, I have some thoughts on this.

@dougrathbone just filed an issue with this same request (#61).

I was thinking it would be better to simply support executing multiple transforms (including more than 2). In that case when the pub-int.ps1 is executed when prompted for transforms to execute you could enter something like the following.

```
    Transforms: release, qa, qa01
```

Where the following transforms are executed in the order below.
1. web.release.config
2. web.qa.config
3. web.qa01.config

What do you guys think?
I think I can run with that!

FYI currently transforms are executed with msbuild.exe from pub-int.ps1. Now that XDT has been shipped on NuGet I can remove this and just invoke straight through PS.
As a part of this work I'm gonna refactor to not call msbuild.exe for the transform.
FYI I've created a new issue to track updating how transforms are executed #63.

OK I think I have something which is working here.

I've published a pre-release on nuget.org. You can try it out by executing the following command in the package manage console.

```
    install-package PackageWeb -pre
```

It should install PackageWeb 1.1.11-beta2 (or higher).

When you run `Publish-Interactive.ps1` and are prompted for the transform to execute you can pass in multiple transforms by separating them with a semi-colon `;`. For example if you want to run the following transforms
1. web.release.config
2. web.sayedsample.config

You will enter `release;sayedsample`.

Please try it out and let me know what you think and if you run into any bugs.

I am running the deploy process within a VS2012 command prompt and my projects are all .NET 4.5.

The issue here is that PS on platforms < win 8 uses .NET 2.0 CLR. I'll need to find a way to invoke the PS script with .NET 4.0 available.
I will need to do some research on this. If you have any ideas the best way to achieve it I'd appreciate the comments.

The only way I know of is to wrap the PSH processes with a config that tells it to run using the latest CLR.  See http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2094694/how-can-i-run-powershell-with-the-net-4-runtime
Registry hack or app.config pick your poison http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2094694/how-can-i-run-powershell-with-the-net-4-runtime

I don't need to run the entire script using 4.0 CLR. I think I should do the following.
1. Refactor the transform part into a separate file
2. Create a .exe to invoke it
3. Call the .exe from the main script

For the last step I can use the PowerShell class http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/system.management.automation.powershell(v=vs.85).aspx.

Let me know if you have any better ideas.

@rmagruder where are you hosting it? The value for the site name is the name of the website in IIS. You'll need to provide the name of a site which already exists. `Default Web Site` is the default when you create a new IIS web server. If you are publishing to a hoster you'll need to get the publish settings from them.

If you are trying to publish an app under a website then you use the syntax `"<sitename>/<appname>"` from what I can tell you are trying to just publish to the site root so it would be `<sitename>`.

It is being hosted on a server on our NT Domain.  It's not a hosting site.  Just one of our WIndows 2008 servers on our corporate network.  "Default Web Site" already exists.   In the Web Deploy publish Dialog in Visual Studio, the 'site name' hints "e.g. Default Web Site/my Site" and that's the format I put it in, which is why it's probably the default in the web deploy package.

Wow, without this post I would have given up on PackageWeb and gone a different direction.  I could not get PackageWeb deployments to publish to a nested site. After trying various combinations I found that this works:
1. in the SetParameters.xml:
   - set the IIS Web Application Name  to "Default Web Site"
2. in the PublishConfiguration:
   - $settingsFromUser += @{name="IIS Web Application Name";value='Default Web Site/Service'}
   - $settingsFromUser += @{name="Computer name";value='https://[domain]:8172/msdeploy.axd?site=Default Web Site'}
3. in Publish-Interactive.ps1
   ~ line 630:
   Change this: $compNameCommandFrag = ",ComputerName='{0}?site={1}'" -f $compNameFixedUp, $siteNameParam.Value
     To This:     $compNameCommandFrag = ",ComputerName='{0}'" -f $compNameFixedUp
Thanks for the bug report, will look into this.

@kpartusch thanks for the request. In general as long as your code works I'll take it in any shape.

If you're asking what I think would be ideal, then continue reading. When I created PackageWeb I was very new to PowerShell. Because of that the code isn't the prettiest and likely does some funny things.

Since then I've improved and I'd like to ensure that new code is good quality. For functions I'd like them to have
- `[cmdletbinding()]` attribute
- Some comments in the form of PS help (doesn't have to be much)
- Should support pipeline when it makes sense
- Should use `Write-Verbose` for diagnostic messages

For an example of how I write PowerShell these days see one of my other repos for ex: https://github.com/ligershark/psbuild/blob/master/src/psbuild.psm1.

You can now pass in the Web Deploy parameters as a command line parameter.

### How to use with a PublishConfiguration.ps1

If you are using a PublishConfiguraiton.ps1 you can just add the parameters to the end of the call to `Publish-Interactive.ps1` as follows.

```
.\Publish-Interactive.ps1 "Computer name=waws-prod-bay-001.publish.azurewebsites.windows.net:443;Password=your-password-here'
```

If a parameter exists in both PublishConfiguraiton.ps1 as well as the command line, the command line value wins.

### How to use without a PublishConfiguration.ps1

If you want to pass in all the Web Deploy parameters, and not use a PublishConfiguration.ps1 file then you need to additionally pass in the `-NonInteractive` switch.

```
.\Publish-Interactive.ps1 -NonInteractive 'Computer name=waws-prod-bay-001.publish.azurewebsites.windows.net:443;Password=your-password-here;IIS Web Application Name=sayedsample;Username=$sayedsample;Allow untrusted certificate=true;whatif=true;TransformName=release'
```

I have a drop for testing available at https://dl.dropbox.com/u/40134810/PackageWeb/issue-42/PackageWeb.1.1.8.11.zip.

#34 will take some time.
Currently the approach that PackageWeb uses is to extract out the .zip file
to a temp folder, perform the transforms in that location. After that
msdeploy.exe is called with that folder as the ArchiveDir.
Since we want to avoid expanding out the entire package I'll have to change
it to: identify transforms w/o extracting any files, extract selected
transform, perform the transform, copy the .zip file, update the web.config
in the .zip file and then kick off msdeploy.exe.

It may be a bit before I can get to that. I will need to block some
dedicated time just for this.

<PropertyGroup>

    </PackageDependsOn>
</PropertyGroup>

<Target Name="AddReplaceRuleForAppPath" Condition=" '$(EnableAddReplaceToUpdatePacakgePath)'=='true' ">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <_PkgPathFull>$([System.IO.Path]::GetFullPath($(WPPAllFilesInSingleFolder)))</_PkgPathFull>
  </PropertyGroup>

  <!-- escape the text into a regex -->
  <EscapeTextForRegularExpressions Text="$(_PkgPathFull)">
    <Output TaskParameter="Result" PropertyName="_PkgPathRegex" />
  </EscapeTextForRegularExpressions>

  <!-- add the replace rule to update the path -->
  <ItemGroup>
    <MsDeployReplaceRules Include="replaceFullPath">
      <Match>$(_PkgPathRegex)</Match>
      <Replace>$(PackagePath)</Replace>
    </MsDeployReplaceRules>
  </ItemGroup>
</Target>
```

Resolved by commit c0e4107479de2885aabf4ed8ccceb4cc31ebaea9.

### Usage

To override the temp directory in the same PowerShell window that you will execute `publish-interactive.ps1` declare the following.
    $pkgWebOptions["tempFolder"]="C:\Temp\publish\temp"

If you are using `PublishConfiguration.ps1` you can set this value in that file as well.

### Files

if($pkgWebOptions -and $pkgWebOptions["tempFolder"]){

I've got a bug here, thanks for letting me know. The fix is straight forward but I don't have the time at this minute to make it. 

In the mean time in the publishconfiguration.ps1 you can declare the temp folder in the following manner.

```
$global:pkgWebOptions =@{}
$global:pkgWebOptions["tempFolder"]="C:\temp\publish\01\a"
```

I have fixed this. You can now override the temp folder used by adding the following `PublishConfiguration.ps1` 

```
$global:pkgWebOptions =@{}
$global:pkgWebOptions["tempFolder"]="C:\temp\publish\01\a"
```

You can find a drop for testing at https://dl.dropbox.com/u/40134810/PackageWeb/issue-31/PackageWeb.zip. Please re-open if you still have issues.

git-hub would rather not know your username and password at all :smile: It asks for them only once: to create a token for further authentication, this token is then stored either in a file, or in your configured credential helper.

Passing a username and password on the commandline is insecure in shared environments: everybody can read those while the process is running. Reading the username and password from a file would mean that they need to be in a file in the first place, which I'd rather avoid too. The token already ends up in a file.

Well, I guess it would at least give the browser a chance to render it. But if you have maaany tabs open and Firefox needs to start first, it can need a quite long sleep. Why not let the file sitting there in the temporary directory? If you are concerned about filling up diskspace, you could add some logic so that if you call render the next time all generated files that are older than X are deleted. If firefox needs to start, webbrowser.open() doesn't return until it has started, so the sleep(1) is sufficient there. It's only when firefox is already running, that webbrowser.open() returns before firefox even attempts to open the file.

Hm, interesting. It is less a problem of timeout. FF just won't render the file from the temp directory. If I move it somewhere else it renders it, if it is in the temp folder it refuses to render anything
No, it is not about the folder. If I copy the file in the same folder it is rendered fine
More probably some issue with the tempfile mechanism that is used

>  tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile([mode='w+b'[, bufsize=-1[, suffix=''[, prefix='tmp'[, dir=None[, delete=True]]]]]])
> 
>    This function operates exactly as TemporaryFile() does, except that the file is guaranteed to have a visible name in the file system (on Unix, the directory entry is not unlinked). That name can be retrieved from the name attribute of the returned file-like object. **Whether the name can be used to open the file a second time, while the named temporary file is still open, varies across platforms (it can be so used on Unix; _it cannot on Windows NT or later_)**. If delete is true (the default), the file is deleted as soon as it is closed.
Thanks for that, I completely missed or forgot that. Will rethink how this is done, ideas welcome. Ideally something that auto-cleans.

This works for me:

```
with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(suffix='.html', delete=False) as fd:
    fd.write(html.encode('utf-8'))
    fd.close()
    webbrowser.open('file://' + fd.name)
    time.sleep(1)
    os.remove(fd.name)
```

While of course it still does not allow viewing the source of the file, but for that you can still use --save as fallback or use Firebug to some extent.

But what to do if you have a `editor = something` set?

Update:

I finally managed to get it working, by including the wordpad path to env. I think this was very much a corner case as apparently `cmd` on windows doesnt know the path of wordpad automatically, which is where `shell=true` redirects, but `powershell` knows it automatically even when it is not in the env path.

**So, not at all a mistake from `git-spindle`. It is fixed.** :smiley:

**But I think there is another interesting thing too:**

I saw that `_getitem` tries all env path and also append `.exe` to search for the file on Windows, but when I used just `editor=wordpad` i.e. without the `.exe`, it never actually reached that function. First `_call_` tries to resolve it via popen and just fails, so without `.exe` it will probably never actually reach that `.exe` adding stuff.
Intriguing. I can reproduce that here. Looks like it clones the right thing, but then set-origin gets confused.

Solution:
- set_origin needs to be less dwim-y (don't try to find a repo in your account)
- fork, clone etc. need to pass a repo to set_origin so it doesn't need the dwimness

Ok. So for Fedora 21 at least ~/.local/share/bash-completion/completions/ is actually loaded (without adding extra stuff to my bashrc). However it only loads completion files there matching them with the executable name. So for example if i add a script called "pip" there it would complete against the "pip" command. This will never work for git subcommands though. 

Hm... _looks further_

Hm. It seems like `/etc/bash_completion.d/` is fairly widely supported for just autoloading a bunch of scripts (without the auto-loading stuff that happens under `/usr/share/bash-completion/completions/`).

I'm not very familiar with python and setup.py, but if it's possible my suggestion is to install into `/etc/bash_completion.d/` when doing a system install and under ~/.config/bash_completion.d/ on a `--user` install. And then in the docs say that you need to add something like the below to your .bashrc.

```
for comp in ${HOME}/.config/bash_completion.d/ /* ; do
    if [ -f "${comp}" ] ; then
        . $comp
    fi
done
```

Either that or just install it _somewhere_ and say that people need to symlink it to whatever directory they use for their completion scripts.

Intriguing. Is this actually on gitlab.com or on your own instance? The title (your email address) should be in `pkey.title`, not `pkey.key`.

This is our own server (GitLab 7.10.0), however I don't think that's significant. The value of `pkey.key` is exactly what I imported into GitLab (copied from my `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub`), and this includes my e-mail address. This is standard OpenSSH format.

I know it is the standard OpenSSH, but the GitLab api is not supposed to return it that way. The algorithm and key parts go in `pkey.key` and the title part goes in `pkey.title`. gitlab.com and gitlab 7.7.2 on my own server both do that, so I guess this is a new bug in 7.10.

I'm not a big fan of $XDG_CONFIG_HOME, so I haven't actually looked at the downsides of doing this. Won't this break on e.g. osx and windows?

...ouch. Can't believe I forgot that.

That said, neither git nor gitk themselves seem to care either, at least from reading the commits I've linked. If the environment variable is empty, nothing breaks  it'll use the spec-defined default, `~/.config/git/`. (That's the case on most Linux systems too.)

On Windows (with Cygwin) and FooBSDs, many users likely already have programs using `~/.config/` too. (Dotfiles aren't a Windows thing anyway. It would be ideal to use AppData I guess.)

On OS X, the new path is just a little bit unusual. (Unfortunately I don't know what paths _are_ usual...)
- I could add a whitelist or blacklist for `os.name == "posix"` or similar.
- I could swap the order so that `~/.gitspindle` remains the default in new installations, with `~/.config/git/spindle` as the fallback path.
- I could make it use `%APPDATA%` on Windows, and [something] on OS X.
- I don't want to withdraw the patch unless it's explicitly rejected. (Even though more and more programs migrate to ~/.config and ~/.cache, I still have 5 ~/.dotfiles than regular files, and I'd like to clean them up.)
Can we somehow get git to tell us what config file it uses? Then we can use that to calculate our path :)

Regarding OSX I think the default folder for config files like these are `~/Library/` which would mean `~/Library/git/spindle.conf` I guess. However since `git` doesn't integrate with default settings folders on any system except for Linux I'd say just follow their example (which is what @grawity 's patch does).

EDIT: did a quick search and couldn't find any other way to find the path to the local git config than just re-implementing the logic git does (which to be fair isn't very complex).

The logic in git is the other way around than what this patch is proposing: $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/.git/config is only used if it already exists. Otherwise ~/.gitconfig is used. So on a system where neither exists, ~/.gitconfig is used. I will implement the same logic as what git does, thus rejecting this PR.

Found the issue, and it's not really intuitive. You need to login() first to set authentication data, that way a GitHubSession is used. It's also necessary to do this in a separate object, or else the user/pass will be used after authorization instead of a token, which will prompt for more 2fa atempts. No, that's not correct either: a force push is only needed if you are rewriting history. A branch can simply be legitimately behind. Though that should be detectable with some `git rev-list` magic.

I know our team does a lot of git commit --amend's locally and rebasing before pushing to the repo and do a lot of rebasing, so we find this capability important.   It may be fine for individuals but not necessarily for group collaboration where rebasing is a constant hassle.

I can put another gitconfig option to allow force pushes to occur if that works better.

I understand, and think it's a good thing to be able to do this, but push -f by default is very bad. What I suggest instead is:
- Branch does not exist? Offer to push.
- Branch is simply behind? Offer to push.
- Branch has diverged and needs push -f? Offer to push -f

Detecting the difference between 2 and 3 should be doable with the correct git rev-list magic, avoiding the need for another config variable and making it work out of the box.

http://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/:

```
Create a pull request

POST /repos/:owner/:repo/pulls
Input

title
Required string
body
Optional string
base
Required string - The branch (or git ref) you want your changes pulled into. This should be an existing branch on the current repository. You cannot submit a pull request to one repo that requests a merge to a base of another repo.
head
Required string - The branch (or git ref) where your changes are implemented.
```

Yeah, I'm afraid that this is outside python-hpilo's control. More and more os'es and python distributions drop support for older ssl/tls versions. You'll need to use an older python version and maybe even an older os (to get an older openssl) to upgrade your ilo firmware to a version that supports modern tls versions.

I've traced it back to this line that was added somewhere between v4.3 and v4.4.1:
https://github.com/seveas/python-hpilo/blob/8880f692d347e1ac7d0b0de993325d70b69c38aa/hpilo.py#L403

It's problematic on e.g. `Python 3.9.0` on MacOS, where using the above code results in this ssl.SSLError: `('No cipher can be selected.',)`, but changing that line the following way (to drop "RC4-SHA") makes it work again:
```diff
-self.ssl_context.set_ciphers("RC4-SHA:" + ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
+self.ssl_context.set_ciphers(ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
```

I don't fully understand why Python/SSL simply won't ignore this cipher that it maybe doesn't support in that version. [Documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl.SSLContext.set_ciphers) states:
> If no cipher can be selected (because compile-time options or other configuration forbids use of all the specified ciphers), an SSLError will be raised.

`ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS` in this version of OpenSSL evaluates to `DEFAULT:!aNULL:!eNULL:!MD5:!3DES:!DES:!RC4:!IDEA:!SEED:!aDSS:!SRP:!PSK`.

However, digging into the definition of [CIPHER LIST FORMAT (v1.1.0)](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/man1/ciphers.html), I see a note about the `DEFAULT` cipher group alias:
> DEFAULT
The default cipher list. This is determined at compile time and is normally ALL:!COMPLEMENTOFDEFAULT:!eNULL. **When used, this must be the first cipherstring specified**.

For OpenSSL v1.1.1, [it says](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.1/man1/ciphers.html):
> The cipher list can be prefixed with the DEFAULT keyword...

Indeed, when moving the "RC4-SHA" to the end to let "DEFAULT" be first, there is no ssl.SSLError exception thrown:
```diff
-self.ssl_context.set_ciphers("RC4-SHA:" + ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
+self.ssl_context.set_ciphers(ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS + ":RC4-SHA")
```

I can't tell whether RC4-SHA will actually work as I don't have iLO that supports it and likely this version of Python/OpenSSL would not, but I believe is a generally more compatible way of expressing the original intention of this code.

Tested on:
> Python 3.9.0 (default, Nov 21 2020, 14:55:42)
> [Clang 12.0.0 (clang-1200.0.32.27)] on darwin
> ssl.OPENSSL_VERSION = 'OpenSSL 1.1.1h  22 Sep 2020'
Thank you!

I figured out what the actual issue is: the xml parser magic turns the privileges you get from the ilo into integers and not single-digit strings. So when you feed those back in, *those* are the ones that are not iterable (strings are iterable just fine). 728c085 fixes it.

Yes, this sounds like the issue I had. Was so long ago that I had trouble remembering what the actual problem was.

Thanks for fixing it.

Hi, it's currently in my git repo under examples/ca/ - requires the certsrv python module listed above and you can add the following under the [ca]: 

server = your-msca.example.com
ca_login = mscaUser
ca_password = M$caPass

Then you can do ./hpilo_msca -l ilouser -p ilopassword sign ilo-fqdn.example.com 

Or ./hpilo_msca -s msca.example.com -L mscaUser -A M$caPass -l ilouser -p ilopassword sign  ilo-fqdn.example.com

It's not perfect, but I wanted you to get a chance to test, etc and I'll see if I can fix any issues. Currently, the one thing I have a problem with is more of an ILO2 issue than anything.

To anyone else bashing their head against this issue, you don't need to use a chroot or an old version of Python. Here:
```example.py
import re
import ssl

import hpilo

ilo3_context = ssl.create_default_context()

# Start with the default cipher set
ciphers = ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS

# Remove any explit prohibition against 3DES
ciphers = re.sub(r":!3DES", "", ciphers)

# Add on DES-CBC3-SHA, as that apears to be the 'best' cipher suite supported
# by iLO3 v1.89
ciphers = ciphers + ":DES-CBC3-SHA"

# Use the modified cipher suite list
ilo3_context.set_ciphers(ciphers)

# Allow SSLv3
ilo3_context.options &= ~ssl.OP_NO_SSLv3

# Disable any attempt at verifying the cert
ilo3_context.check_hostname = False
ilo3_context.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE

iloc = hpilo.Ilo(
    "somehost", "someuser", "somepassword", timeout=5, ssl_context=ilo3_context
)

# Do stuff!
```

Works OK for me under Python 2.7.14, against G7 systems running iLO3 version 1.89. Should work under Python 3.6/3.7 as well, but I haven't tried.
Verified this worked on Python 3.6 (on win10 box).  Thanks for solving as it was driving me nuts.  Tested against G7 system running ilo3 with firmware ver 1.91.

@Shados This really depends on the distribution. In Debian Stretch sslv3 is deprecated and removed. You just can't use it. The reason it worked for @sharp99 is that he's using a windows 10 box where sslv3 is probably still enabled.

What worked for me (without sslv3 on debian stretch) is going to the ilo web interface > Administration > security > Encryption tab > Enforce AES/3DES Encryption > Enabled. Combining this with version 4.3 of python-hpilo fixed all issues for me.

Awesome! Thanks for reporting bugs

This doesn't help against attacks. What would prevent the attacker who can change the .scexe files in flight from also changing firmware.conf?

And it has *very* limited value against accidents: the firmware is already signed and the iLO won't accept anything that's corrupt.

So I'll need to be convinced a lot more before accepting this idea :smile:

Good that I still have a few arguments queued up then :)

That is a valid point which is outside of the scope of this issue but also needs to be handled. There is one answer with a few implementations. Digital signatures. Linux distros do this quite well for many years now. PIP allows to upload signatures but not to check them. Git has good support for it. In your case, as you download the file on runtime, you would need to check the signature each time. GnuPG and OpenSSL come to mind.

> the firmware is already signed and the iLO won't accept anything that's corrupt.

Do you have details on that signature or is it just a checksum you can calculate yourself? Or perhaps some home-brown crypto which will break if you look at it (example [mec-tools](https://github.com/eigenmatt/mec-tools))?

The thread model I had in mind was https://downloads.hpe.com gets compromised. There is a reason software deployment uses locally verified signatures or if the origin is not able to provide signatures, use locally verified checksums.

The only new argument I see in that reply is 'what if the firmware verification is weak?'. I don't know the details of the firmware verification, but am not aware of any tools to break it or any published weaknesses, so that argument is pretty weak as well.

Linux distro signatures are bootstrapped by embedding trusted keys on the install iso. So when you trust the iso, you trust the updates. For firmware.conf, that bootstraping is a lot more difficult, and due to the firmware verification on the iso itself not quite worth it.

downloads.hpe.com getting compromised is about as likely as github.com getting compromised, so checksums in firmware.conf also don't really add anything there.

So I hope you have more arguments :)

> For firmware.conf, that bootstraping is a lot more difficult, and due to the firmware verification on the iso itself not quite worth it.

Not necessarily. Your Python module is in Debian (https://packages.debian.org/search?keywords=hpilo). When you now harden the down-streaming path too, for example, Debian by implementing #184 you are pretty far with mitigating the bootstrapping problem.

> but am not aware of any tools to break it or any published weaknesses, so that argument is pretty weak as well.

Having dealt with a few firmware formats and looking into reversing and patching one of them ([thinkpad-ec](https://github.com/hamishcoleman/thinkpad-ec/)) I have my doubts for every security feature which can not be reviewed (free access to the source code and build chain) so I would still recommend to do this additionally in python-hpilo. Also, we have no idea how good HPE is with keeping their private keys private. Their website setup does not look too well done at some parts. There is a reason why https://github.com/rootkovska/codehash.db exists. Lets bump our thread model up once more: Targeted attacks.

At least the HPE docs have some details on this:

> Authorized firmware updates  iLO firmware images are digitally signed with a 2048-bit
 private key. The boot block checks the digital signature every time iLO comes out of reset.
iLO checks the digital signature before allowing a firmware update to proceed. Remote
flashing requires login authentication and authorization, including optional two-factor
authentication.
> 
> Image Validation
> The entire image is hashed with SHA256 and signed using Hewlett Packard Enterprises RSA
2048-bit private key. This signature block is pre-pended to the firmware binary image.
> 
> Boot-Time Integrity Check
> At boot time, each piece has its signature validated before it is allowed to execute. Subsequent
pieces are checked by the previous ones until iLO is fully booted.

Source: https://support.hpe.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=c04530504

Sounds reasonable, at least when they keep increasing their RSA key size. 2048 bit is not really state of the art anymore.

#184 doesn't help Debian unless they actually check the signature, and nothing tells me they do. It's also only one of the distribution channels, and unfortunately people will just add any old gpg key to the apt or yum/dnf keyring that they find these days.

I'm afraid that the scaremongering about targeted attacks also doesn't work for me. Feel free to maintain a list of firmware hashes yourself, but I still don't think that the added work adds enough value to make it worth it.
@seveas When we are now talking about the extra work, one could just automate that. I addressed your other points in #184.
You might be interested: https://airbus-seclab.github.io/ilo/SSTIC2018-Slides-EN-Backdooring_your_server_through_its_BMC_the_HPE_iLO4_case-perigaud-gazet-czarny.pdf
Yeah, that's quite the SNAFU there :smile:

Thanks! I still don't quite like the argument names though, but I'll fix that up myself as I didn't comment on it earlier (and really only thought of it after rereading your updated version) :)

--ssl will become --ssl-version
--ca-file will become --ssl-ca-path and no longer automatically enables checking
--ssl-verify enables checking
--ssl-match-hostname=no disables the hostname checking

That way all ssl arguments start with --ssl

Oh bugger. This is a bit trickier as match_hostname, and some of the ssl things I also want to achieve really only work in 2.7.9 or newer, and I still support 2.4. Also, centos 7 only has 2.7.5 by now.

This may need more backwards compatibility work.

I've bitten the bullet and removed python 2.4/2.5 compatibility, which makes this somewhat easier, but also makes this pull request even harder to apply. What I think I'll do is make --ssl-verify only work on 2.7.9 and newer and die otherwise. That way we can have the best of both worlds.

927a40a is what I eventually came up with. For hpilo_cli, you can still specify the for ca path and hostname checking, but in the python code I wanted more flexibility and instead of many ssl parameters, it now accepts an ssl context to use. hpilo_cli creates such a clontext, based on the --ssl-* parameters.

As I said earlier: this is limited to 2.7.9 and newer. I've made the code error out decisively when trying to do verification on older versions.

the keys are:
ilouser -> security_name(username)

for AUTHN_PROTOCOL: 0 or 1
0 is for MD5,
1 is for SHA

for PRIVACY_PROTOCOL: 0 or 1
0 is for DES,
1 is for AES

AUTHN_PASSPHRASE
PRIVACY_PASSPHRASE

for more information
http://h20566.www2.hpe.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=c03334058

Unfortunately that looks like a broken iLO, not much python-hpilo can do about that. Here's what I would do:
- Try to reset the ilo using hponcfg and the iLO kernel driver (run this locally on the server: hpilo_cli localhost reset_rib) 
- If that doesn't work: Power down the server. Remove power cables if it's a discrete server, remove the blade from the chassis if it's a blade. Then power it back up
- If it still doesn't come back, contact HP support.

FYI this is a piece of XML I run for several years to configure my ILO using `hponcfg`:

``` xml
<RIBCL VERSION="2.0">

  <LOGIN USER_LOGIN="admin" PASSWORD="password">

    <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
      <FACTORY_DEFAULTS/>
    </RIB_INFO>

    <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
      <LICENSE>
    <ACTIVATE KEY="@@ILO_LICENSE@@"/>
      </LICENSE>
    </RIB_INFO>

    <SERVER_INFO MODE="write">
      <SERVER_AUTO_PWR VALUE="Random"/>
    </SERVER_INFO>

    <USER_INFO mode="write">
      <ADD_USER USER_NAME="Nagios Monitor"
            USER_LOGIN="@@ILO_NAGIOS_USER@@"
            PASSWORD="@@ILO_NAGIOS_PASSWORD@@">
        <ADMIN_PRIV value="N"/>
        <REMOTE_CONS_PRIV value="N"/>
        <RESET_SERVER_PRIV value="N"/>
        <VIRTUAL_MEDIA_PRIV value="N"/>
        <CONFIG_ILO_PRIV value="N"/>
      </ADD_USER>

      <ADD_USER USER_NAME="root"
            USER_LOGIN="@@ILO_ROOT_USER@@"
            PASSWORD="@@ILO_ROOT_PASSWORD@@">
        <ADMIN_PRIV value="Y"/>
        <REMOTE_CONS_PRIV value="Y"/>
        <RESET_SERVER_PRIV value="Y"/>
          <VIRTUAL_MEDIA_PRIV value="Y"/>
          <CONFIG_ILO_PRIV value="Y"/>
      </ADD_USER>
    </USER_INFO>

    <RIB_INFO mode="write">
      <MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS>
        <ENABLE_NIC VALUE="Y"/>
        <SPEED_AUTOSELECT VALUE="Y"/>
        <NIC_SPEED VALUE="10"/>
        <FULL_DUPLEX VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_ENABLE VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_GATEWAY VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_DNS_SERVER VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_WINS_SERVER VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_STATIC_ROUTE VALUE="N"/>
        <DHCP_DOMAIN_NAME VALUE="N"/>
        <REG_WINS_SERVER VALUE="Y"/>
        <REG_DDNS_SERVER VALUE="Y"/>
        <PING_GATEWAY VALUE="Y"/>
        <IP_ADDRESS VALUE="@@ILO_IP_ADDRESS@@"/>
        <SUBNET_MASK VALUE="@@ILO_IP_NETMASK@@"/>
        <GATEWAY_IP_ADDRESS VALUE="@@ILO_IP_GATEWAY@@"/>
        <DNS_NAME VALUE="@@ILO_HOSTNAME@@"/>
        <DOMAIN_NAME VALUE="@@ILO_DOMAIN@@"/>
        <PRIM_DNS_SERVER VALUE="@@ILO_DNS_SERVER1@@"/>
        <SEC_DNS_SERVER VALUE="@@ILO_DNS_SERVER2@@"/>
        <TER_DNS_SERVER VALUE="0.0.0.0"/>
        <PRIM_WINS_SERVER VALUE="0.0.0.0"/>
        <SEC_WINS_SERVER VALUE="0.0.0.0"/>
    <STATIC_ROUTE_1 DEST = "0.0.0.0" GATEWAY = "0.0.0.0"/>
    <STATIC_ROUTE_2 DEST = "0.0.0.0" GATEWAY = "0.0.0.0"/>
    <STATIC_ROUTE_3 DEST = "0.0.0.0" GATEWAY = "0.0.0.0"/>
      </MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS>
    </RIB_INFO>

  </LOGIN>
</RIBCL>
```

And as you can notice, the first commands are very similar as the XML you generated `FACTORY_DEFAULTS` and `LICENSE` in their own `RIB_INFO` and this works.

@renard 
I have some experience dealing with iLO scripting.  Basically, you are executing two commands in one XML script that you need to put in two separate XML scripts:

The FACTORY_DEFAULTS tag causes iLO to erase its NVRAM and schedule a reboot.  Now, here is the catch:  The iLO reboot starts as soon as the XML parser sees the closing RIB_INFO tag.   Anything you add after that closing RIB_INFO tag may not execute properly because, even though the XML parser keeps executing your script, iLO behind the scenes is already preparing itself to go for a reboot and sometimes iLO reboots really quick.    

Because of this behavior, I've seen cases where some iLO settings could get corrupted.  I had this problem few years ago and I contacted HP support.  They told me to separate the XML scripts,or change the order of Tags in order to leave the one that triggers the iLO reboot to the end.

These scripts below will always work.  But, you need to wait until iLO comes back from reboot which could take ~1 minute.

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.0">
 <LOGIN PASSWORD="********" USER_LOGIN="Administrator">
  <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
    <FACTORY_DEFAULTS />
   </RIB_INFO>
 </LOGIN>
</RIBCL>
```

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.0">
 <LOGIN PASSWORD="********" USER_LOGIN="Administrator">
  <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
    <LICENSE>
      <ACTIVATE KEY="123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP" />
    </LICENSE>
  </RIB_INFO>
 </LOGIN>
</RIBCL>
```

@renard 
I know your script used to work but, it doesn't anymore.  I had the same problem few years ago when a couple of my iLOs would end up with corrupted SNMP settings.  
My script had multiple RIB_INFO sections just like your script and, since the first section of my script was making changes to iLO network settings (MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS), all my iLOs were  rebooting at the end of the first RIB_INFO section.  
The result was a totally unpredictable behavior where some of my iLOs were getting correct SNMP settings while others were not. My iLOs were all at the same firmware level but, on different server models. Yet, they behaved differently. It was a disaster.

HP support told me to never add extra RIBCL sections after one that is known to trigger an iLO reboot. Any MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS change will cause iLO to reboot so, will FACTORY_DEFAULTS by the way.  Making the suggested changes to my script solved my problems for good.

Basically, HP support told me that if you see this response coming from iLO:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.23">
<RESPONSE
    STATUS="0x0000"
    MESSAGE='No error'
     />
<INFORM>Integrated Lights-Out will reset at the end of the script.</INFORM>
</RIBCL>
```

Any RIBCL section you see executing after this message is not guaranteed to succeed because, iLO is in the process of shutting down. In other words, iLO has began closing its doors and windows and, turning off the lights one by one in order to go for a reboot.

Having poked at this a bit, I have to conclude that it's unfixable. Neither the HTTP header, nor the XML document contain any encoding information. So as a best-effort, we try to interpret whatever we get as latin-1, but realistically anything non-ascii may trigger errors and bugs.

doable

That may be a fix in your case, but it doesn't work in general. The iLO is supposed to escape all non-ascii characters in the xml output it generates, as that is the only way it can convey encoding of multi-byte characters. So I cannot accept that as a fix.

While I agree that it feels kinda specific I'd say that:
1. it doesn't escape characters
2. Some of these strings can be user supplied or corrupted (which it is in
this case)

My personal opinion is that it shouldn't die from this but it would be nice
if it warned...

Your patch is wrong. The data must be ascii-only, and we need to fix that as soon as we get data in, not when we feed it to the XML parser, so things like saving to files works too. The only way to do that is when decoding, and the only way to do that properly without breaking the chunked encoding is to replace non-ascii bytes with ascii characters. The questionmark seems most suitable.

Yes, when talking to the iLO via the kernel driver, no authentication is done and any password is accepted. Resetting forgotten passwords is one of the things that is made possible by this. This is a feature of the iLO itself and this cannot be changed. So if you want to manage passwords of the local iLO, you'll need to check them via the network interface I'm afraid.

I don't actually see an error there. The 404 is the protocol detection that tries an http request, which on iLO1 will fail and this tells the protocol detection logic to use raw sockets. Ok, i tried it on another ilo-1 box i found. I got this:

Despite those 404 errors and warnings, the new cert is actually installed. It's just that this ilo version does not reload post certificate upload.

No version of iLO actually resets itself after a certificate upload, which is just one of the many inconsistencies in the iLO firmware, as for example changing the hostname does reset the iLO. Not much python-hpilo can do about that :smile:
I think ilo-4 versions i tested actually reboot by default. Could be a configuration option i have not found yet. I assumed this was the default behavior.

You do that by setting the iLO's hostname (note not fqdn!):

```
hpilo_cli your.ilo.ip mod_network_settings dns_name=your-ilo-name
```

In commit 36109b63, there was a backwards-incompatible change in `update_rib_firmware`. If you use a custom progress function, you now need to do the line-clearing in that function. See hpilo_cli's `print_progress` function for an example.

I have updated HP ILO 4 to v2.10 still not luck..
I'm afraid that `get_cert_subject_info` is an obsolete feature, only supported by iLO2. The certificate request certainly looks valid to me though. What's the problem with it?

ummm.. well by default ILO4 add subject alternative names with hostname which my CA don't allow to sign. it requires only FQDN .. and I didn't find any way to skip SAN's from CSR using ILO GUI and python module. also when I am generating CSR it from python module CA shows that CSR is invalid. as mentioned in previous post output .. 

Is there any way to capture CSR output to proper way ?

The SAN issue is not something that is configurable I think, though if you can find an API that lets you do so, I'd love to know about it.

The formatting issue is because you don't print your response properly. Do `print(a.certificate_signing_request())` for a properly formatted CSR.
By the way, most people I know use an internal CA for signing iLO certs. As they shouldn't be visible externally anyway, a properly trusted internal CA is cheaper to use.

We are also using internal CA but It's restricted by security policies .. 
I didn't find any API in hp ilo 4 .. even newer REST API for HP ILo seems to be interface to their ssh based console over web service.. http://h20564.www2.hp.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=c04423967
I've taken another look at the API, and I'm afraid you'll have to tell your CA to simply ignore the SAN's. There is no way of generating a CSR without them.

Just to add some more notes that HP  ILO4 firmware version 2.54 seems got the feature where someone can exclude or include IP for subject alternative names. By default HP ILO 2.54 version don't include IP address now, only FQDN included.
Thank you! I probably won't merge this as is but turn it into a set of smaller patches, so please be patient while I do so.

I've finally found some time to look at this again. In commit 5f6a076 I am taking an alternative approach, but with the same outcome: SAN's are added to certificates and there's retry logic for when the certificate takes a while to generate.

I also like the idea of allowing country etc. in the config file, so I added that too.

Thanks!

Thanks for spending the time doing this. There are a couple of things that I changed since then and that was the 
default_md       = sha1
to 
default_md       = sha265

Also added "localityName           = optional" to the req_policy.

The first change is to prevent errors and the second is to include the locality in the certificate so it is shown in the iLO.
Thanks, both these changes make sense, so I've added those as well and they'll be in the next version.

To generate a patch for changes you already committed: git format-patch origin/master

> One thing that would save even more time is the generation of the

That would be a nice idea. I don't generally visit iLO's this way, but
can see that it would help in other use-cases. It would require a new
certificate when the IP address changes though, but that's not a big
deal.

There's also the problem that the iLO generates the CSR, so we have to
mangle it to include the subjectAltName (and hope the iLO actually
supports this.

I was using the 2.9 release but the code hasn't changed much, so the 
patch may apply. One thing to note is that when requesting a CSR it can 
take the iLO about 12 mins to prepare one. I've only tried this with iLO 4.

> > One thing that would save even more time is the generation of the
> > certificates that work with the onboard administrator. They open a new
> > window using the IP address of the iLO and not the host name. This
> > means that the certificate needs a DNS alias for the IP addess as well
> > as the unqualified host name.
> 
> That would be a nice idea. I don't generally visit iLO's this way, but
> can see that it would help in other use-cases. It would require a new
> certificate when the IP address changes though, but that's not a big
> deal.

With blade enclosures the on-board administrator is the easiest way to 
go as all 16 blades are accessible from one interface. From there we can 
click onto the individual iLOs and their remote consoles.

> There's also the problem that the iLO generates the CSR, so we have to
> mangle it to include the subjectAltName (and hope the iLO actually
> supports this.

This does work, I used hpilo_cli to generate the CSR, It seems that the 
iLO need the FQDN of the host to accept the certificate and any change 
to the network settings causes the certificate to reset to the default 
useless one. The CSR generated by the iLO includes a subjectAltName for 
the FQDN and the host name but not the IP address. So I have to add one 
when signing the request. I wasn't sure if this was possible with 
openssl but found the answer that it is possible (from TinyCA). I 
manually signed the certificate and imported it with the import 
certificate command. It worked and no more untrusted certificate.

BTW I think that HP have broken their RIBCL commands with iLO4 version 
2.10 as they now return an error saying "Error writing xml_header", I've 
a case with HP about this error message.

Kind regards
Duncan Webb

It's not `call_delayed` that returns the list of dicts, that's `get_host_data` itself. Similarly, `get_fw_version` returns a single dict, whether it's run  as part of a delayed call or not. `call_delayed` does not (and should not) change the return type of any of the called function. If it does, that is a bug.

Here's an example from the command line, the `+` makes it use `call_delayed`.:

```
$ hpilo_cli 10.1.2.3 get_fw_version
>>> pprint(my_ilo.get_fw_version())
{'firmware_date': 'Aug 26 2011',
 'firmware_version': '1.26',
 'license_type': 'iLO 3 Advanced',
 'management_processor': 'iLO3'}

$ ./hpilo_cli 10.1.2.3 get_fw_version + get_uid_status
>>> pprint(my_ilo.get_fw_version())
{'firmware_date': 'Aug 26 2011',
 'firmware_version': '1.26',
 'license_type': 'iLO 3 Advanced',
 'management_processor': 'iLO3'}
>>> print(my_ilo.get_uid_status())
OFF
```

That makes no sense to me at all. The returned items are all different, because they are returned by different functions. Treating them as one block of data is definitely not the way to approach this.

call_delayed is a shortcut to avoid some overhead in the iLO, not a way of grouping together completely unrelated data.

I'm not sure I understand your bugreport. As far as I can see, the returned dict contains all attributes of both the smbios_record node (b64_data and type) and the field tags (Family and Date). Am I overlooking something?
OK, I've overlooked that you have attribute "type" included in json output. I was only missing the outer smbios_record.

`get_all_licenses` only works on iLO3 and iLO4.

You may want `get_fw_version` instead:

```
>>> pprint(my_ilo.get_fw_version())
{'firmware_date': 'Aug 26 2011',
 'firmware_version': '1.26',
 'license_type': 'iLO 3 Advanced',
 'management_processor': 'iLO3'}
```

I do not think this is a good idea. You can specify dicts on the command line as follows:

`hpilo_cli ... mod_snmp_im_settings snmp_address_1_trapcommunity.value=trapper snmp_address_1_trapcommunity.version=v2c`

That said, you'll need the bug fix I just did in bf1ac69. I forgot to mark the trapcommunity parameters as requiring a dict, so `hpilo_cli` would not allow one.

Thanks for the debuginfo. Unfortunately, pasting it here really mangles the output. Could you please mail me the generated file as an attachment? (dennis@kaarsemaker.net)

The debug output does show that it's definitely a bug in python-hpilo, so once I have the debug output, I will fix it asap.

It's actually a bug in the ilo3 firmware, it's misspelling `NIC_INFORMATION` as `NIC_INFOMATION`! A workaround is now in commit d1cc8fa. If this workaround works on your systems I will issue a bugfix release of python-hpilo.

Please issue a bug fix.
It works great in my environment.
Thanks a lot!

notifications@github.com> wrote:

I fixed this literally 8 minutes before you reported it :smile:

That's great! I can now safely re-download from pip without having to patch those lines each time.

Thank you :)
Not quite yet, the fix is not yet in a released version (it will be in the next few days, maybe even today)

It is actually a bug in the ilo firmware ~~that I _think_ locfg.pl works around (or it has the same bug, I've not actually investigated)~~ _and_ locfg.pl: In XML documents, an & needs to be escaped, the XML generated by python-hpilo does this correctly. However, the iLO firmware does not properly unescape the password field.

I'm a bit hesitant to "fix" python-hpilo, so I would recommend working around this by using a password that does not contain a & character.

I understand your point of view, you want to respect XML standards.

But as this is a bug in iLO and your code is only designed to work with iLOs (as far as I know ?), maybe would it be good to make it works ?

Regards.

It's not just about standards. Fixing this is going to require really nasty hacks to make sure it works on all supported python versions. Look at how the CDATA support in hpilo.py is implemented and think "three times uglier".
Actually, I've come up with a fairly OK way of doing this. At least it doesn't make me hide in the corner with shame. See commit 095d784, which will be in the next release.
Thanks, it's great ! Many thanks for your reactivity.

Your environment is messed up. You're using a python 3.4 stdlib with python 2.6/2.7. This will never work and is in no way related to anything python-hpilo does.

Ah, no, I need to read better :) You're using python-hpilo 2.6, not python 2.6 :)

Looking at the actual output: you're using a buggy version of the iLO firmware that uses single quotes to quote attributes. I believe python 3.4's elementtree will barf if it does that. Please upgrade the firmware of this iLO device.
Fixed in 02dca19

That was undocumented functionality that I honestly thought nobody used :smile: 

I'll put it back in a different shape, maybe as part of hpilo_cli.
It's now (b8bdf8f) part of `hpilo_cli` and documented.
Awesome! Thank you!
Thanks, both make sense. Applied as 0582eb4 and 6c692f2

Thanks for the bugreport. Can you run this command and share the output please:

```
hpilo_cli -dd your.ilo.ip.here get_fw_version + get_embedded_health
```

Anonymysed versions are hard to parse. If you don't want the output to be publicly visible, please run the following command:

```
hpilo_cli your.ilo.ip get_embedded_health --save-response=for_dennis.txt
```

and mail the generated for_dennis.txt to dennis@kaarsemaker.net - any anonymisation you want to apply should be done only by replacing characters with the same number of characters, so do not add more characters or remove parts of the data.

Ah, that's two interesting things: the 'safety catch' failed, and iLO now supports updating the firmware like this. Or maybe it always did and I misread the documentation. I will fix both things, but for the failing safety catch it would be helpful to know the exact command you used to try to update the firmware with hpilo_cli.

This is the command I was attempting to use: hpilo_cli localhost update_rib_firmware filename=/tmp/foobar/ilo4_132.bin

I think I see why the safety catch failed- the test is comparing against the string ILO_LOCAL instead of the value of ILO_LOCAL

```
        if self.protocol == 'ILO_LOCAL':
            raise ValueError("Cannot update iLO firmware using hponcfg")
```

I found an old [HP advisory](http://h20000.www2.hp.com/bizsupport/TechSupport/Document.jsp?objectID=c03691604) about issues upgrading using hponcfg- perhaps that's why you were checking for it?

Oh, that's a rather embarrassing error :)

Commit 19b9c21 (and newly released version 2.5) removes the restriction and tells hpilo.py not to bother with uploading if the protocol is ILO_LOCAL (without quotes). I've tested this on a G8, updating ilo4 firmware from 1.20 to 1.30, which works. Thanks for the report and the help!
That commit unescapes _all_ ampersands, it should only unescape the ones in the password. And even that's icky. But if it works, then I'll apply it.

An example would be the `print_progress` function in `hpilo_cli`. The method gets called with progress strings that either start with a newline and ansi 'erase line' or just a normal string. Ah crap, bug in the output sanitizer, making it show incorrect XML :)

Anyway, I'm afraid the bug is not in python-hpilo, but in your expectations. AHS, and thus GET_AHS_STATUS is only supported in iLO 4. The fact that the iLO returns 'Syntax error' is a [known issue](http://seveas.github.io/python-hpilo/troubleshooting.html#syntax-error-line-0) which is annoying but impossible to fix in python-hpilo.

Cheers,
Gunnnar

    message = self._parse_message(data)
  File "/appl/env/bin/python/lib/python2.6/site-packages/hpilo.py", line 436, in _parse_message
    raise IloError(message, status)
hpilo.IloError: Syntax error: Line #0: syntax error near "" in the line: ""
```

It is possible, but there are a few problems with it:
- It requires me to maintain that list
- The iLO version isn't always known to the code yet, so the exception handler may need to do another XML call to get that version 
- There are functions where this is a per-argument thing (mod_global_settings comes to mind)
- There may be actual genuine syntax errors due to bugs

So, so far I've not been in favor of that, and instead warned about it in the documentation. I may catch the error and reraise it with a diffetent message, such as 'Syntax error: Line #0: syntax error near "" in the line: "". You may have tried to use a feature this iLO version does not support'
I've now added that in adee97b.

Gunnar

Unfortunately there's not much you can do. The XML interface for the iLO simply is slow. There's only one optimization: store the ilo type or protocol in your asset database. That way you avoid the one request overhead for each new Ilo object to find out which protocol to use (raw for ilo/ilo2, http for ilo3/ilo4)

Actually, there is a way to speed it up: iLO interfaces accept multiple commands in one XML document. In the soon to be released python-hpilo 2.0 you can use this as follows:

```
>>> ilo = Ilo(..., delayed=True)
>>> ilo.ilo.set_vm_status('cdrom', state, True)
>>> ilo.warm_boot_server()
>>> ilo.call_delayed()
```

With a bit of reordering to minimize the amount of calls to the iLO, you should be able to speed up hpilo_boot. hpilo_facts can't be sped up as it only does one call anyway.

I was trying to fix an issue in NaiveBayesGenerator and I noticed that some tests were failing once in a while. It made it hard to figure out if it was my changes or something else so I decided to fix the fails separately.

Here is a longer description of the changes I made. Note that there were many ways to prevent the fails. Let me know if you would have preferred another approach.

**LearnerPrediction and Prediction fails**: This was mainly caused by the fact that the test datasets are quite small. Since the train/test samples are selected randomly we were sometimes _unlucky_ and the accuracy was not satisfying. Considering that by using a 0.8 ratio of train vs test samples on a 14 samples dataset, this leaves only 3 test samples. The current minimum accuracy was 0.75 which would not allow even one fail. I reduced this to 0.66 and increased the _repeat_ from 10 to 100.
Another recurring fail was that the _best_ model couldn't always predict the hardcoded sample for Iris even when the model accuracy was high. Looking at the [scatterplot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iris_flower_data_set#/media/File:Iris_dataset_scatterplot.svg) for Iris I noticed that SepalLength and SepalWidth were a little bit off from what we would expect of Iris-Setosa so I adjusted these values.

**Index out of range exception**: The GenerateModel() method in Learner.cs was extracting the potential labels from the test set. In a context of low test samples it often happened that the test set didn't even include all the trained labels. When the model would (_wrongfully_) predict a label which was not in the test set it would lead to an invalid descriptor label index. I added a parameter to prevent updating the labels list. Another way to repair this could have been to clone the descriptor from the train set but I found no clone method for Descriptor.

Note that some numl tests are still failing but they are unrelated to my changes. I might give them a look once I fixed NaiveBayesGenerator...

The StringLabel attribute inherits from Label for the purposes of predicting string types which allows models to perform inference accordingly.  To avoid exceptions you should decorate strings as the StringLabel attribute if you're attempting to use them as the model target.

You can also do model.PredictValue(object o) if you just want the label prediction (and not have the system fill in the value). Sometimes the type cannot be written to so this call makes more sense.

I've been looking into the innards of the descriptor building mechanism for this, and I have a question. 

`Discrete` is defined as a property on the `Property` class:

```
public bool Discrete { get; set; }
```

This works for both normal features/properties as well as enumerable ones, because enumerable properties are all of the same type. But if we have a complex type with discrete and non-discrete values, then how would this be resolved?

As far as I can tell, `Discrete` is only used for logic flow in two places (currently in portable):
[line 225 in DecisionTreeGenerator.cs](https://github.com/sethjuarez/numl/blob/portable/numl/Supervised/DecisionTree/DecisionTreeGenerator.cs) and [line 35 in NaiveBayesGenerator.cs](https://github.com/sethjuarez/numl/blob/portable/numl/Supervised/NaiveBayes/NaiveBayesGenerator.cs). 

I would think the `NaiveBayesGenerator` can be ignored I would think, because it is a label and I wouldn't think labels should be complex types (though perhaps I'm wrong?).

But with the `DecisionTreeGenerator` (and possibly other future algorithms), we definitely have logic based on this. 

One possible change to address this could be changing the `Discrete` from a bool property to a `IsDiscrete(int i)` virtual method, and maybe giving it a default value to show its usual use: `IsDiscrete(int i = 0)`. This would also need changes in the serialization aspects as well I think. 

Thoughts?

**Discrete** is an interesting artifact of assuming that there would always be a one-to-one correspondence between a property and a single (double) value. Under this assumption there were two categories of numbers (in my original opinion): 
1. Discrete - binary and small subset of integers 
2. Everything else

This worked well under the above mentioned assumption - not so sure when there is a one-to-many correspondence between a property and the generated numbers.

An additional assertion - the descriptor was never intended to be used to flatten object graphs into vectors. My hope was that there would first be a projection onto a flattened structure that would subsequently be described by the descriptor. I initially went down this path but quickly realized I would be re-implementing a lot of what already existed in AutoMapper. This is why I put work into the descriptor working even with anonymous types (it does). You could theoretically flatten into an anonymous type and couple it with a weak descriptor.

What do you think?

Hmm...I think the discrete/everything else split was a good decision. 

As for your additional assertion, it has been my understanding that the descriptor is the OOP-to-math bridge, enabling the wrapping/consumption/simplification of the ML complexities in object terms (the main reason I chose numl in the first place). As such, I personally like the object graph flattening being encapsulated in the descriptor and I appreciate your distinctions of strong/weak descriptors in the [comments of your blog](http://sethjuarez.com/2013/04/08/descriptors-in-numl/).  So I think that was a good decision also.

And using those terms, this issue is simply an implementation detail of a strong descriptor, and I think it can be done as you mentioned by creating custom `Property` and `Attribute` classes (which is what I've done so far). I might just have to tweak the `Discrete` property, possibly by making it a virtual property with (obviously) its current implementation as the base implementation. This would avoid a breaking change and also allow the mapping process to handle the one-to-many relationship of properties to matrix numbers. If I can, then it's conceivable I could do an attribute as is mentioned by @bdschrisk to provide some kind of syntactic sugar for this.

I don't know for sure though, I just wanted to get your thoughts on this before going ahead. I'll go ahead and try to implement this `Discrete` tweak and see how it looks. Though I haven't dug into your process of math mapping back to the descriptor (label) just yet, it _should_ work (famous last words)...I've been meaning to get some kind of T-shirt and/or coffee mug made: 

"That _should_ work! 8-O"

Unfortunately we can't add such functionality because of limitation of [Android DownloadManager](https://developer.android.com/reference/android/app/DownloadManager) which is used in android native part. Hi guys! Finally, we did it! ([PR#61](https://github.com/sgrebnov/cordova-plugin-background-download/pull/61))
I added latest code in my app but no notification appeared need help.

If the App is closed then there is no way that any app related code can run - so yes all actions would terminate. Unfortunately there is no AppClose event to listen to - only Pause 
https://cordova.apache.org/docs/en/latest/cordova/events/events.html

But in Android, we can hand over download to default download service after which the download will not stop even after closing the app. And it does work on Android. But similar thing does not work in iOS.

In this plugin it is mentioned in quirks that "If a download operation was completed when the application was closed, onSuccess callback is called right after the first startAsync() is called for the same uri, as if the file has been downloaded immediatly."

But in my case, the download is paused when app is in background and resumes only in when app is active. Hence, the download will never be completed in background when app is closed.

Sorry my fault. Missing 

`<preference name="AndroidPersistentFileLocation" value="Compatibility"/>`

in config.xml

Hi @Snyz2016, we've made a number of improvements related to such issues. Now you can specify internal storage as target location. Yes - the contents of the X-Forefront-Antispam-Report header are the source for that section, so I included them verbatim as the source header. Are you saying that's wrong? Why do you call out that the header value start with CIP? Is that not correct?

> Is this expected new design change?

I realized there were fields in the antispam reports that weren't getting parsed out. Some of them were documented, some weren't. The documented ones get parsed out and the remaining ones are unknown fields. In case anything about the parsing is wrong, I also show the original header untouched.

> Shouldn't be kept as "X-Forefront-Antispam-Report" in "Other headers"?

After the work I did on the antispam report parsing, the extra copy down in other headers became redundant, so I removed it. I did the same with the received headers, to, from, subject etc that all appear in their own sections. None of them belong in Other so I removed them. Are you saying this was the wrong choice?

Figured out what's going on. If you go look for message headers in OWA right now, all leading spaces are stripped. So while the header in proper RFC format should look like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6773183/90790763-6c88ba00-e2d6-11ea-9178-f7e51add20a2.png)
from OWA, it looked like this:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6773183/90790855-86c29800-e2d6-11ea-8b36-f5c8ee2ee41c.png)
with no leading spaces. To any header parser, this looks like a new header named CIP.

This is a bug in OWA that likely affects parsing of several headers. I'll have to see if I can do anything to handle this bad data better.
BTW - this only affects standalone with user supplied header text. Add-in pulls the headers itself and has no problem.

Has there been any action on this item? I can concur that this is an issue when pulling the message header manually from OWA. Is there anything that I can do to rattle the cage for the OWA team on this? Has there been any acknowledgement or interest? Thanks.

>  Is there anything that I can do to rattle the cage for the OWA team on this?

You'd need to report the issue to the OWA team first.

I opened a ticket in mid February through Office 365 Partner Support. It was eventually elevated to the product team. The product team hasn't officially reported back on the ticket yet, but according to my testing, message headers are now formatting correctly via OWA and can be parsed by MHA.

Aha - 9020 is from outlook-*.js - the call is coming from inside the house:
$h.OutlookErrorManager.OutlookErrorCodes.genericResponseError=9020;
$h.OutlookErrorManager._addErrorMessage$p(9020,"GenericResponseError","");

Places which log 9020:
1. _loadDictionaryRequest
2. SaveDictionaryRequest - used by saveAsync
I use both of the above, but we're getting this error from an EWS request, which is the third place this is logged:
3. handleResponse - when wasProxySuccessful is false.

Which leads to these possibly related reports:
https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100031398
https://www.veritas.com/support/en_US/article.100033597
https://vox.veritas.com/t5/Enterprise-Vault/Failed-to-send-a-request-to-the-Exchange-Server-OWA-2013/td-p/670279

And this tantalizing blog post which describes the proxy in more detail:
https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/emeamsgdev/2014/09/19/troubleshooting-exchange-2013-mail-apps-executeewsproxy-calls/

Possible conclusion: This error is due to misconfig on the Exchange server.
Possible fix: Put up a page describing how to troubleshoot and fix misconfig, then redirect users getting 9020 to this page.

The add-in is installed to either your Exchange server or your mailbox. It's not installed to Outlook. So re-installing Outlook wouldn't do anything. Maybe you installed MHA via your [Exchange Admin Center](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj150562(v=exchg.160).aspx), perhaps even using a manifest file. 

Here are the steps from the front page of this GitHub on managing an add-in via the EAC. You should be able to reverse them:
- Go to the Exchange Admin Center.
- Click on the Organization tab
- From there, select the add-ins tab
- Click the Plus icon/Add from the Office Store
- A new page will load for the store
- Search for "Message Header Analyzer"
- Choose MHA in the results
- Click Add
- Confirm by clicking Yes
- Back in the Exchange Admin Center, refresh the list of add-ins
- You can now edit who the add-in is available for

Stephen,

I found the cause of my problem.
We use a Haproxy server to connect to our webmail.
It was too secure prohibiting the tls 1.0.
By reactivating the Tls1.0, MHA works perfectly.
That's good info - I think maybe I can pass a header to avoid needing tls 1.0...I'll need to do some research
Pretty sure error parsing work has fixed or drastically changed this one.

This might be the same issue as #38, which I now think was caused by moving the rest/ews calls into a frame. I'm working on pulling them back out and leaving the frames to just to rendering, which should fix #38, and then we'll see if it fixes this.

BTW - this didn't happen to be working at the start of the year did it?

Stephen,
We found the solution.  If you are doing EWS filtering as we are you need to include "Mozilla/*" in the list.  I basically kicked off fiddler and attempted to use MHA and noticed that the user agent was "Mozilla/...".  After adding that by performing the following powershell statement it all started working.  Thanks for your help.

set-organizationconfig -ewsallowlist "Outlook-Android/\*","Outlook-iOS/\*","ExchangeServicesClient
/\*","\*outlook\*","\*MAPI\*","\*skype\*","Microsoft+Office/\*","UCCAPI/*","OC/\*","OCPhone/\*","Microsoft Office/\*","MacOutlook/\*","Mozilla/\*"
Good find - I'm reporting this to the devs - this is non-obvious...

"YOU SHOULD NOT BE HERE" does not exist in the current version of the add-in. That's an old error message which I've since updated. I've also in the meantime updated my caching headers to force reloads.

So - what's going on:
1 - Outlook for iOS put out an update which broke one of the libraries I used.
2 - I coded a workaround and shipped it
3 - Since my old pages had no caching headers, Outlook for iOS isn't looking for the updated pages.

One thing which I know will fix this is to uninstall Outlook for iOS and reinstall. That will force it to download MHA again and get the new files (with proper cache headers so this shouldn't happen again). If anyone finds a less drastic workaround please speak up and thank you!
Also - I think Outlook for iOS' next update will fix the problem which broke MHA in the first place, so you might start working again, but still with the old version of the app...

Since this is OWA, you can use F12 debugging to watch the requests. The first request we'll make is for GetClientAccessToken. So you can check if you got back a token or an error from that. If that worked, we then make a request for the transport header. The request URL will look like this:
https://outlook.office365.com/api/v2.0/me/messages/<id>?$select=SingleValueExtendedProperties&$expand=SingleValueExtendedProperties($filter=PropertyId eq 'String 0x007D')

I presume one of these two calls is the one that failed.

That code means the server/message store was asked to do multiple things (like delete or move) and was able to accomplish between zero and all of them. And also that it did not return an error.
How do I delete the message? I keep getting this error when I try to delete it.

It seems to indicate that the message store (or server) is failing to delete the message.  The error doesn't tell you enough to now why the delete is failing.  

If this is connected to Exchange, the most common reasons for delete failure are:
1) Recoverable Items is over quota (so you can't delete any more)
2) The message is marked for submit. (Common especially if the message is in sent items or drafts). You could try using MFCMapi's "abort submit" feature to unmark the message from submit, then see if it lets you delete it.

Otherwise, you'd have to get someone (probably support) to help you figure that out.
The "abort submit" worked beautifully. Thank you so much!
